basics.name: Davis M. Welakuh
basics.label: Researcher and HPC Applications Engineer
basics.summary: A highly skilled High-Performance Computing (HPC) Application Engineer with focus on computational physics and chemistry software. Extensive experience in developing, optimizing, and scaling scientific and engineering applications for large-scale HPC and AI systems.

work.name: Hewlett Packard Enterprise, NY, USA
work.position: Senior HPC Application Engineer: Computational Physics and Chemistry
highlights: Develop and optimize HPC applications for computational physics/chemistry simulations on multi-core CPU and GPU-based systems, improving performance.
Collaborate with scientific researchers to profile and identify bottlenecks in large-scale computational physics/chemistry applications, optimizing memory usage and reducing computational times.
Perform system-level tuning, benchmarking, and performance evaluations on national supercomputing clusters such as Frontier and NERSC.

work.name: New York University, New York NY, USA
highlights: Conducting theoretical and computational research in areas of quantum system engineering and nonlinear frequency generation for applications in quantum information processing protocols and nanoscale sources of extreme ultraviolet light.
Collaborating with other scientist (theorist and experimentalist) providing expertise in areas of physical system modeling, quantum system engineering, Big Data and statistical analysis.
Scientific peer review work in top scientific journals.
Active developer and maintainer of my Python-based scientific software, LIBQED.

work.name: University of California, Los Angeles CA, USA.
highlights: Conducting theoretical and computational research in areas of quantum system engineering and nonlinear frequency generation for applications in quantum information processing protocols and nanoscale sources of extreme ultraviolet light.
Collaborating with other scientist (theorist and experimentalist) providing expertise in areas of physical system modeling, quantum system engineering, Big Data and statistical analysis.
Scientific peer review work in top scientific journals.
Active developer and maintainer of my Python-based scientific software, LIBQED.

work.name: Harvard Univeristy, Cambridge MA, USA.
highlights: Conducting theoretical and computational research in areas of quantum system engineering and nonlinear frequency generation for applications in quantum information processing protocols and nanoscale sources of extreme ultraviolet light.
Collaborating with other scientist (theorist and experimentalist) providing expertise in areas of physical system modeling, quantum system engineering, Big Data and statistical analysis.
Scientific peer review work in top scientific journals.
Active developer and maintainer of my Python-based scientific software, LIBQED.

work.name: Max Planck Institute for the Structure and Dynamics of Matter, Hamburg, Germany.
highlights: Conducted theoretical and computational research on controling or modifying properties of matter interacting strongly with photons within quantum electrodynamics environment using first-principles methods.

Extended well-known linear-response Casida and Sternheimer methods for calculating matter properties within time-dependent density-functional theory formalism (DFT) to quantum electrodynamical density-functional theory (QEDFT) that treats strongly coupled matter-photon systems.
Contributed to the programming and development of the open-source scientific software octopus, in a collaborative team environment.
Developed my own Python-based multi-purpose computational software known as LIBQED, to investigate the exact properties of strongly coupled matter-photon systems.

volunteer.summary: Lead organizer for the New York City branch of the People's Climate March, the largest climate march in history.
highlights: Awarded 'Climate Hero' award by Greenpeace for my efforts organizing the march.
Men of the year 2014 by Time magazine

awards.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
awards.summary: The Nobel Prizes are five separate prizes that, according to Alfred Nobel's will of 1895, are awarded to 'those who, during the preceding year, have conferred the greatest benefit to humankind.'

publications.name: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
highlights: Quantum Teleportation
Quantum Cryptography
